testcase: How to make an interface internal ?

expected.answer: We do not support hiding an entire operation group directly. The recommended approach is to redefine your client in client.tsp to control which operations appear on the public client. When you do this properly, the default service clients and their Operations classes should not be emitted—as long as you remove all previously generated SDK output before regenerating. Or you can use _patch.py to customize the code.

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: How to make an interface internal ?\\n\\nquestion: I am looking for ways to make an interface internal so that it does not appear in public interface of python SDK. This is the interface which emits `EvaluationResultsOperations` which shows up on client. I would like to generate it but keep it hidden from public interface.\\nI tried following:\\n1. Mark all operations under it internal\\n2. Adding @access decorator to interface but that fails.\\nIs there a way to achieve it ?\", \"response\": \"To make an interface internal so that it does not appear in the public interface of the generated Python SDK, you should use the `@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")` decorator from the Azure.ClientGenerator.Core library on the interface itself. However, simply marking the interface or its operations as internal is not sufficient if any public operation references the interface or its models, as access is propagated from usage.\\n\\nThe correct approach is:\\n- Apply `@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")` to the interface you want to hide.\\n- Ensure that none of its operations or models are referenced by any public operations or models. If any public operation references them, those types will be promoted to public regardless of the decorator.\\n\\nExample:\\n```typespec\\nimport \\\"@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core\\\";\\nusing Azure.ClientGenerator.Core;\\n\\n@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")\\ninterface EvaluationResultsOperations {\\n  @access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")\\n  op getEvaluationResults(): EvaluationResult;\\n}\\n\\n@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")\\nmodel EvaluationResult {\\n  value: string;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nIf you do this and ensure that `EvaluationResultsOperations` and its models are not referenced by any public operations, they will not appear in the public Python SDK client.\\n\\nIf you still see the interface in the public client, double-check that no public operation or model references it, directly or indirectly. Access is propagated, so any public usage will override the internal marking.\\n\\nThere is no supported way to generate the interface but keep it hidden from the public client if it is referenced by public operations/models. The suppression or patching approach is not recommended and not supported by TypeSpec best practices.\", \"ground_truth\": \"We do not support hiding an entire operation group directly. The recommended approach is to redefine your client in client.tsp to control which operations appear on the public client. When you do this properly, the default service clients and their Operations classes should not be emitted\\u2014as long as you remove all previously generated SDK output before regenerating. Or you can use _patch.py to customize the code.\"}"}]
groundedness_reason: The response is fully grounded, accurate, and complete, directly reflecting all relevant details from the context without introducing errors or omissions.

For more details on templates, [see templates](./templates.md).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface ReadWrite\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  read(): T;\\\\r\\\\n  write(t: T): void;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Templating interface operations\\\\n\\\\nOperations defined within an interface can also be templated. For more details on templates, [see templates](./templates.md).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface ReadWrite\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  read(): T;\\\\r\\\\n  write\\\\u003cR\\\\u003e(t: T): R;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nalias MyReadWrite = ReadWrite\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nop myWrite is MyReadWrite.write\\\\u003cint32\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n:::caution\\\\r\\\\nAny templated operation defined in an interface that is not instantiated will be omitted from the list of service operations.\\\\r\\\\nThis also applies when using `extends` on an interface that contains templated operations with unfilled template arguments.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface ReadWrite\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  read(): T;\\\\r\\\\n  write\\\\u003cR\\\\u003e(t: T): R;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\ninterface MyReadWrite extends ReadWrite\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e {} // Here, the `read()` operation is fully instantiated and will be included in a service definition. If not set, the decorator will be applied to all language emitters by default.\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003eYou can use \\\\\\\"!\\\\\\\" to exclude specific languages, for example: !(java, python) or !java, !python. |\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| scope   | `valueof string`                                                            | Specifies the target language emitters that the decorator should apply. If not set, the decorator will be applied to all language emitters by default.\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003eYou can use \\\\\\\"!\\\\\\\" to exclude specific languages, for example: !(java, python) or !java, !python. |\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\r\\\\n##### Basic client definition\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nnamespace MyService {\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@client({\\\\r\\\\n  service: MyService,\\\\r\\\\n})\\\\r\\\\ninterface MyInterface {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Changing client name\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nnamespace MyService {\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@client({\\\\r\\\\n  service: MyService,\\\\r\\\\n  name: \\\\\\\"MySpecialClient\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n})\\\\r\\\\ninterface MyInterface {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#conversionfix.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Fixing Converted TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/conversionfix\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Fixing Converted TypeSpec\\\\n## Fixing Linter Rules\\\\n### @azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#conversionfix.md\\\\n\\\\n# Fixing Converted TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Fixing Linter Rules\\\\n\\\\n### @azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi\\\\n\\\\nThe `operationId` in OpenAPI file is usually formatted as `OperationGroup_OperationName`. Use [`@clientLocation`](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/typespec-client-generator-core/reference/decorators/#@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.clientLocation) to specify the operation group and [`@clientName`](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/typespec-client-generator-core/reference/decorators/#@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.clientName) to change the operation name if needed.\\\\r\\\\n**Before:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  @operationId(\\\\\\\"OperationGroup_Get\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**After:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.clientLocation(Employees.get, \\\\\\\"OperationGroup\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n// Note: @clientName is not needed here because the operation name \\\\\\\"get\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n// matches the \\\\\\\"Get\\\\\\\" part of the original operationId\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"language-basics#visibility.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Visibility\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/visibility\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Visibility\\\\n## Lifecycle visibility\\\\n# language-basics#visibility.md\\\\n\\\\n# Visibility\\\\n\\\\n## Lifecycle visibility\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec provides a built-in visibility called \\\\\\\"resource lifecycle visibility.\\\\\\\" This visibility allows you to declare\\\\r\\\\nwhether properties are visible when passing a resource to or reading a resource from an API endpoint. class:\\\\r\\\\n- `Create`: The property is visible when the resource is created. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `POST` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Read`: The property is visible when the resource is read. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property is\\\\r\\\\n  returned in an HTTP `GET` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Update`: The property is visible when the resource is updated. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `PATCH` or `PUT` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Delete`: The property is visible when a resource is deleted. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `DELETE` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Query`: The property is visible when a resource is passed as a parameter in a query. This visibility is checked, for\\\\r\\\\n  example, when a property is a parameter in an HTTP `GET` operation (**this should not be confused with an HTTP query\\\\r\\\\n  parameter defined using `@query`**).\\\\n\\\\n### Lifecycle visibility transforms\\\\n\\\\nYou can explicitly compute the shape of a model within a _specific_ lifecycle phase by using the four built-in\\\\r\\\\ntemplates for lifecycle transforms:\\\\r\\\\n- `Create\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Create` lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  phase, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Read\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Read` lifecycle phase,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Update\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Update` lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  phase, with the types of the properties set to `CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have _either_ the `Create` or `Update`\\\\r\\\\n  visibility modifiers enabled, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Delete\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have the `Lifecycle.Delete` modifier enabled,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Query\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have the `Lifecycle.Query` modifier enabled,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Update)\\\\r\\\\n  description: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadExample is Read\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel CreateExample is Create\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel UpdateExample is Update\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel CreateOrUpdateExample is operations, models, enums and model properties.\\\\r\\\\nWhen setting access for namespaces,\\\\r\\\\nthe access info will be propagated to the models and operations defined in the
